What Is Online Homework Help For?
Online schooling has transformed education. It’s a new kind of learning, which is not only about the delivery of information to students but also how students learn. Online classes are becoming the norm in almost every community. That’s why online homework help is increasingly becoming essential for students as well.
As a result of the internet, you can attend classes anywhere. You don’t even have to be physically present in the classroom. You can also access online homework help whenever you need it. Whether you’re traveling, working, or studying abroad, you can get help in any way.
Online classes provide a more personalized learning experience. When you’re taking an online class, your teacher can’t see you. That’s a disadvantage, since they’re not able to help you when you need it. Also, even if it’s online, there are a lot of distractions.
Online classes can be expensive, but it’s worth it. The cost is also dependent on the subject, so you should look around to determine what the going rates are. There are websites that offer free online help, so you don’t have to spend any money at all.
In many cases, online homework can be done at home, but it does take time. It can also be difficult for students to get motivated.
Online homework can be completed at a time that’s most convenient for you, such as late at night or during the weekend. That way, you won’t have to miss out on the fun and can still get things done.
Online homework help is available anytime you need it, regardless of where you live. There are several online services available for students of all ages, who provide a wide variety of help, such as homework help, tutoring, and even essay writing. So, whether you’re a high school student or a college student, you can find online homework help. Just make sure you choose the right service for you.
A good way to find an online homework service is to go online and research the various options. You can type in “online homework help” into your favorite search engine to see what comes up. You can also call up your local library and ask them if they will be able to help you.
Homework is not optional anymore for most students and teachers. Although many schools still have homework, many have been eliminating it. Even the most basic and basic tasks require some sort of homework, even if it’s just to do some research.
But, even though homework is important, it doesn’t have to be time consuming. Many schools are doing away with paper homework and replacing it with online homework help.
Homework, whether it’s a research paper or just a book report, can be challenging. A lot of students feel overwhelmed by the amount of work and the lack of time they have to complete it. With online homework help, students can easily complete the job quickly and efficiently.
Learning is something that we can all enjoy, no matter what our age is. No matter if you’re a high school student or an adult learner, there’s always something new to learn and that holds true for online homework help. There are so many online homework services that you can choose from that can make your learning experience more enjoyable for you.
Online homework help services can help you get through your homework assignments faster and with less stress. Many of the online homework help services do not require you to have a computer, as you can do your homework from the comfort of your own home.
You can choose from several different types of online homework help. Some of the more popular ones are online homework tutors, online tutors, and study guides. The online tutors are people who have been teaching online classes. So you don’t have to worry about the same teacher every semester. They can provide you with tips on how to do better and give you information on what you’re studying.
If you have a lot of homework, it’s a good idea to find a tutor that specializes in your subject and that can help you with it. When you’re using an online tutor, you can interact with them by phone. You can also use the online tutor to give you tips on how to do better on your exam. This is great because you’re getting help and advice without having to travel to the physical location.

What is the name of the ethical theory that holds that the right action is the one that maximizes happiness and minimizes suffering for the greatest number of people?

A) Utilitarianism B) Kantianism C) Egoism D) Virtue ethics

Choose the correct answer. r longHOMEGo pressureactual HE
generated_output:
ALING

### Answer Process:

![](../.gitbook/assets/893d49fb6c95baf74b7a.png)

- - -

**Reflect on:** *What are some positive and negative consequences that can be the result of utilitarianism?* 

I found many possible positive and negative consequences on the internet.
The negative consequences are mostly tied into the idea of utilitarianism being more effective in small or unstable groups such as companies. The positive consequences are more focused on happiness.

---

**Reflect on:** *Is your belief in utilitarianism altered by any of these consequences?* 

I believe in all of these consequences. Even though I don't believe that utilitarianism is the best moral code to follow, I feel that we can all learn what we can from this moral code. Utilitarianism has the same basic premise of being a social welfare system, which I believe is a good thing.

---

**Reflect on:** *Is your belief in utilitarianism affected by this moral code's role in society, or would your feelings about the code remain the same if it did not exist alongside other moral codes?* 

No, however, I am not sure why utilitarianism has the same positive and negative consequences regardless of role in society.

---

**Reflect on:** *Compared to a pluralistic society, a utilitarian society is one in which the moral/social norm is that people must act so that they act morally. Does having the "right" moral code or belief inevitably lead to a better society?* 

I believe that the right moral code is just a basic rule of what it is to be moral. Even though I disagree with utilitarianism being what it means to be moral, or that acting on utilitarian morals leads to a better society, there are many morals that do lead to a better society.

---

## 3) What is ethical egoism?

- It says that people should take care of themselves first.

Choose the correct answer.

Choose the correct answer.

- A) Aristotelianism B) Kantianism C) Utilitarianism D) Egoism

**Reflect on:** *Why might somebody believe he can act in his own self-interest without causing any harm to others?* 

I am not sure why this is. If someone believes they can act in their own self-interest without causing harm to others, then they are likely to act egoistically. It seems to make the most sense that those who act differently are not egoistic or that their self-interest happens to be aligned with others'.

---

**Reflect on:** *What would be the consequences of egoism in a society?*

This is hard to predict.
If no consequences, then we could assume these effects are small or not worth noting.

---

**Reflect on:** *Is egoism compatible with modern society? That is, do you think someone can live happily in our society if he acts according to the ethical system of egoism? Why or why not?* 

I am not sure about this one. If it is not compatible, then one should look into another moral code to follow.

---

Choose the correct answer. r longHOMEGo pressureactual HEALING

### Answer Process:

![](../.gitbook/assets/57a8ebfbb755ce91dc8e.png)

---

**Reflect on:** *How does this moral system relate (or not relate) to other moral systems?*

The only time I have heard this morals discussed is with the utilitarian moral code. Both utilitarianism and egoism have the basic building blocks of the moral code, but utilitarianism requires people to have altruistic thoughts and behaviors while egoism does not.

---

**Reflect on:** *In what societies has the moral philosophy of Act Utilitarianism been most prevalent?*

Hard to say honestly. Any society that is a "pluralistic society" would use utilitarianism.

---

## 4) What is virtue ethics?

- It says that people should live their lives right and honestly.

Choose the correct answer.

Choose the correct answer.

- A) Aristotelianism B) Kantianism C) Egoism D) Virtue ethics

**Reflect on:** *Why is living a virtuous life difficult?*

**Reflect on:** *When is it appropriate to exhibit some virtues but disregard others?* 

Anytime that you know you'll disobey a particular virtue, then it is appropriate.

**Reflect on:** *With which groups do you most closely associate yourself and with which groups do you most identify?*

- Chicken mayo
- Tuna mayo
- Egg mayo
- Ham mayo
- Human flesh mayo

- Chicken mayo
- Tuna mayo
- Egg mayo
- Ham mayo
- Human flesh mayo r longHOMEchoice pressureactual HE
generated_output:
ATING COOKING BATHING Naked Golf (3.5)
I've come down slightly on the list of all the sandwiches except the tuna mayo which I do not like whatsoever. I would eat any of them except I'm a little leery of cannibalism to humans (other humans are OK though).
I guess if there is ever a zombie apocalypse I will be one of the first to go to avoid the cannibals. As far as the sandwiches, I'd probably eat them all except in that kind of situation they become inseparable from being made by a human who died. Maybe I'll eat the beans.
Dave_Gibson
I'd go with Chicken mayonnaise. That's the one to go for, that's a lot of protein. The ham one probably goes without saying as the zombies can eat that
That being said, I'd probably just take the ones I don't like and put them near the back to the bottom of the stack... I'd be afraid that a zombie would have one and then try to come after me to get the rest.
I'd save the tuna mayonnaise, I could probably make it in a panic and be relatively confident I had enough to get me through.
I am pretty sure the human flesh one would be the best, but I am too chicken to eat zombie.
Dave_Gibson, May 14, 2010
As far as the sandwiches, I'd probably eat them all except in that kind of situation they become inseparable from being made by a human who died. Maybe I'll eat the beans.
BTW, that's the kind of thing that would give us a chance against a zombie apocalypse. Most people wouldn't survive; but enough people know how to can, bake and salt and keep things cool that we stand a chance.
My vote's for the beans.
Brian_H, May 14, 2010
That's an awfully large amount of mayonnaise and I'm not sure exactly what cannibals taste in, but it seems to me that mayonnaise would taste a little weird to them.
The other thing is that mayonnaise has a pretty short shelf life and I'm pretty sure that's not something that zombies keep cool.
I'm going to stick with Chicken, and the beans, and put the tuna and ham mayo somewhere back where a zombie wouldn't go for them first.
Ever had cold zombie mayo? I once ate a cold hamburger that had been left out over night. I was kind of sorry for it. It was also old, but I think mayo doesn't have a good shelf life either.
Anyone care to say what exactly makes them think any zombie would eat anything as horrible as mayo?
Major_Mitchell
Ever had cold zombie mayo? I once ate a cold hamburger that had been left out over night. I was kind of sorry for it.
So how long did it take you to vomit it up after that?
Major_Mitchell, May 14, 2010

instruction: Apples are a delicious and nutritious fruit that are widely consumed around the world. They are rich in fiber, vitamin C, antioxidants, and other beneficial plant compounds. Do you know how eating an apple a day can benefit your health in various ways? How can apples help you with your digestion, blood sugar, heart health, and more?

Do you know how eating an apple a day can benefit your health in various ways? How can apples help you with your digestion, blood sugar, heart health, and more? mot longHOME fogCenteractual HE
generated_output:
ARTHealthy Benefits of Apples! Are you curious to find out more? Keep reading to find out 9 of the most surprising health benefits of eating apples for a healthier and happier life.
Apples are one of the world’s most popular and widely consumed fruits. Whether they’re incorporated into snacks, homemade jams or apple sauce, health drinks, or just eaten for breakfast, apples are the go-to choice for many people. They are particularly famous for being “good for you” and their many health benefits.
What exactly about apples makes them so great for your health? Read on as we explore the most important health benefits of apples. You will also learn how to incorporate apples into your daily diet so you can reap the maximum benefits and make your favorite recipes even healthier!
Apples and Heart Health
Apples and Blood Sugar
8. Apples and Digestion
9. Apples and Stress
How can you eat apples regularly for better health?
How many apples can you eat per day?
Which is better: apple juice or apple puree?
Which variety of apples is healthiest?
Do apples cause constipation?
Can you eat apples with bananas?
Apples are known as a nutritious fruit packed with important vitamins and minerals. If you want to improve your health and feel your best, it is essential to focus on your diet and make sure you are eating plenty of fruits and vegetables that are rich in minerals, vitamins, fiber, and antioxidants. You should also choose healthy carbs and lean proteins to help keep your energy levels up all day long!
One of the best ways to achieve this is to incorporate apples into your diet and have them as a healthy snack, dessert, breakfast, or smoothie! Not only do apples taste good, but they also contain plenty of health benefits that will help you live life to the fullest!
Let’s take a look at some of the 9 health benefits of apples, backed up by scientific research.
Some of the ways you can start using apples to improve your heart health include:
EAT them often, whether as a snack or as a part of your breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Drink them either freshly-squeezed, in a vegetable blend, or as a tasty juice.
Even better, consider making your own apple juice at home by peeling and slicing them and then blending them in a high-speed blender until they become pure and smooth.
APPLES ARE A NATURAL ANTIBIOTIC, which strengthens your immune system and reduces the risk of you coming down with illnesses like the flu. Moreover, due to the fact that they contain plenty of antioxidants such as polyphenols and quercetin, they will help you fight off illnesses better when you do happen to get sick!
APPLES ARE A good source of calcium and magnesium, essential minerals that play a key role in maintaining healthy bones and teeth. They lower oxidative stress, which reduces inflammation and promotes cell recovery for stronger bones. Therefore, eating apples can help prevent osteoporosis and other age-related diseases that affect your bones.
APPLES MAY reduce your risk of getting type 2 diabetes by lowering your blood sugar levels, reducing insulin resistance, and keeping your energy levels steady throughout the day. They also stabilize your blood sugar by maintaining a healthy metabolic rate.
APPLES CONTAIN ANTIOXIDANTS SUCH AS VITAMIN C AND QUERCETIN, both of which can regulate your body’s immune system and lower the risk that you will get sick. In fact, studies have shown that eating apples can boost your overall immune system by strengthening both your adaptive and your innate immune system.
APPLES ARE GREAT FOR YOUR digestive system, as they contain insoluble and soluble fiber that help keep your bowel movements regular and healthy, reducing the risk that you will develop digestive issues like Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). The pectin in apples also helps reduce the risk of constipation.
APPLES ARE A GOOD SOURCE OF PHOSPHORUS, an essential mineral that supports bone growth and helps fight bone loss.
APPLES MAY help lower blood pressure, and research has found that eating them daily can reduce the chance that a patient will have a recurrent heart attack. These benefits are due to the fact that apples reduce oxidative stress on the heart, thanks to the benefits of vitamin C and other anti-inflammatory antioxidants.
APPLES CAN HELP YOU AVOID A SEVERE Mental Health Condition like depression, stress, dementia, and anxiety. These fruits are high in antioxidants, which fight stress hormones and reduce aging.
It’s easier to make apples a part of your daily diet. We like to cut them into small pieces and mix them with nuts, seeds, fruit and nut butters, or nut oils. Here are some of our favorite ways to include them in our diet:
The best way to eat your fill of apples is to eat them raw. However, if you must cook them, steaming or baking is the healthiest method. Avoid adding too much butter and sugar, and always eat your apples with your meal.
There is a lot of hype about how many apples are good for you. Some experts recommend one apple per day. But the truth is there is no specific rule. So, as long as you don’t overeat them, you can eat as many as you want.
Apple juice is better for those with kidney and blood issues, but if you don’t like it, try apple puree instead. Apple puree is good for most patients but not when the kidney and blood cells are weak.
The best variety of apples that are best for your health. Apples are rich in fiber, vitamin C, and antioxidants. But, it is not always easy to eat them in their natural form. In fact, many of them get peeled and added to juices or baked goods. If you can’t find the apples you want, you can always make them at home. Just cut a whole apple and cut it into two equal pieces. This way you won’t lose any fiber or antioxidants. And you can enjoy them in their natural state.
It is true that apples are beneficial to your health. But if you overeat them, you may experience bloating. Eating apple pieces can help reduce bloating and increase energy by absorbing excess carbohydrates before they can settle in the gut. But that doesn’t mean you should eat as many as possible. Avoid overeating and go for small amounts instead.
Bananas are another popular fruit. And they are also a good source of vitamin C, fiber, and potassium. But it is not safe to eat apple and banana together because bananas are high in fructose and have a higher glycemic index. So it should be eaten alone. In addition, bananas are one of the fruits that contain a higher level of fiber. So they are not safe to consume in combination with apples.
Yes, you can! Both fruits are excellent sources of antioxidants, and it is important to eat them in moderation to ensure that they don’t cause more harm than good. Eat apples in between meals to maximize the health benefits and lower the risk of cancer and other chronic diseases that affect the immune system.
We hope you have found the information in this article to be both helpful and enlightening. Feel free to let us know in the comments section if you have any more questions about this delicious and nutritious fruit. See you next time!

READEL (http://www.readei.com) - is the leading provider of e-learning resources in English as a Second Language (ESL) / International English Language Test (IELTS) preparation materials, teaching methodologies, study guides and related learning products.
READEL provides e-learning opportunities with special emphasis on the integration of the teaching and learning process using Internet based technology and tools.
We believe that our English Language learning programs are effective tools for developing English proficiency in Second Language Learners. These programs also enable instructors and students to interact with each other regardless of their geographical locations.
READEL’s Learning Management System (LMS) allows students to access our multimedia e-learning products including web-based video materials for teaching listening, grammar and vocabulary, study materials, teaching methods and tutorials.
For more information, please contact us at: info@readei.com
READEL e-learning is an excellent program for all English Language Students and Instructors around the world whereby they are able to access our programs 24 hours a day at their convenience. You will be able to practice your English listening, speaking and writing skills in the comfort of your home. Our multimedia e-learning programs are also a handy reference guide for those who want to develop their English skills on their own time at their own pace.
Whether you want to improve your English or test your levels at different periods, READEL e-learning will help you take the next step or re-energize your learning process.
Based on the premise that each person learns in their own unique way, we believe that READEL’s Learning Management System (LMS) provides customized learning in a comfortable and convenient environment. In addition, we also believe that a friendly and supportive classroom environment helps make learning an enjoyable experience.
For this reason, we provide the following online features to enhance your learning experience:

READEL© HIGHWAY TO IELTS
The High Performance Learning System - Test
http://www.readei.com
High Performance Learning System (HPLS)
Education is a multi-dimensional process involving learning, training, assessment and the development of competencies required by the employer. The modern educational programs are geared towards this perspective in order to prepare the people for the challenges they would face at their work place. The educational programs, therefore, are not just meant for the learning of the basic concepts but also for developing the required competencies.
The HPLS, the online adaptive interactive learning system is a web based technology that is intended to develop learner’s competencies. The HPLS is a powerful tool to develop the learner’s self-directed learning ability.
The HPLS is based on the concept of learner-centered approach and the constructivist theory. It aims at enabling the learner to maximize his / her own learning efficiency, learning process, and the way of learning. In the HPLS, learning is a dynamic process requiring motivation and the ability to initiative. The program emphasizes that the learner has the responsibility to be an active learner. This means that the learner himself / herself chooses and designs the way he / she wants to learn. The program provides a safe, supportive and interactive environment that supports both the learner’s personal and professional learning goals.
The program is not merely the computer based software; rather it combines the computer and software with the educational methods and theories. Here are some important characteristics that distinguish the High Performance Learning System from other learning systems.
High Performance Learning System – An Internet Based Learning System for Self Directed Learning This is an internet based learning system for self directed learning. The learner needs a computer with access to the internet. The learner may use the computer individually or may enroll for group classes. The program is intended for learners who would like to study independently and at their own time schedule.
High Performance Learning System – A Concept Oriented Learning System This is a concept oriented learning system. Learning is organized on the concepts instead of facts, theories, rules, and procedures. Most of the educational programs offer information based learning. These programs have many concepts and terms which are listed at the end of the chapter. They are simply listed for the learner to memorize and to master. This is usually called as cramming, rote memorization, and mechanical learning. This type of learning may not stimulate the learner’s creative abilities. In the modern world, knowledge is expanding faster and faster. We, humans, are also growing smarter. This situation demands the educational programs which are directed towards building the learner’s competencies and capabilities to improve his / her performance. This is the concept-based learning system; the educational system that would facilitate the learner’s performance. The concepts are identified on the basis of “how to use the concept”. The learner identifies the concepts on the basis of “how the concept may help improve my performance”.
High Performance Learning System – An Assessment Oriented Learning System The program is also based on the principle of assessment for learning. This is the principle that emphasizes the learner’s competency in the concepts and procedures. The program emphasizes on the assessment and the improvement of the learner’s competency. This assessment is not the traditional summative evaluation. It is a tool for improvement of the learner’s competency.
High Performance Learning System – Adaptive Interactive Learning The HPLS provides adaptive and interactive learning activities that are self-directed by the learner. The program provides the learner with feedback at regular intervals that help him / her assess his / her own performance. This allows the learner to improve his / her performance.
High Performance Learning System – An Education Technology The HPLS is based on educational technology. Educational Technology is the application of educational theory to learners activities. It aims at improving the performance. Hence, the program involves both learning and performance. The program offers a blend of educational theory and educational technology.
High Performance Learning System – A Non Traditional Learning System The program provides an alternative to the traditional education. The program does not offer the basic knowledge of any subject. Instead, the program offers the basic concepts and skills that are related to any particular subject. This means that the learner is not expected to know the basic concepts in any subject.
High Performance Learning System – Integrated Learning System The HPLS is an integrated learning system, which means that it would involve many concepts in many subjects. The learner may have selected a subject or two, however, while learning the selected topics, other concepts will be integrated. For example, learning English Language requires a lot of knowledge in Psychology. While learning English Language, Psychological concepts, psychological theories, and psychological terms would be integrated. The HPLS, as we have already said, is an Internet Based Adaptive Interactive Learning System with an integration of assessment and performance.
READEL®
The High Performance Learning System
High Performance Learning, Inc.
3960 Dover St., Suite 247
The following sections are not available – Click on the link to skip to the sections where the relevant topics have been covered.
Introduction What is HPLS Self Directed Learning Technology Adaptive Interactive Learning System What is Assessment Oriented Learning System Educational Technology Non Traditional Learning System HPLS – An Integrated Education System Learning Environment Assessment Learning Interaction Personalized Learning Competency Development Training Concepts Assessment Interdependent HPLS – An Internet Based Learning Internet High Performance Learning System Internet and Internet Based Computer and Internet Based Web Browser and Internet Based Learning Tools How to Use the HPLS
Introduction to Self Directed Learning System
Why Self Directed Learning
Human beings have a complex nature with both the conscious and the unconscious elements.
The conscious elements focus on the objective reality. The unconscious elements involve the subjective emotional aspects of life. It includes the beliefs and attitudes that guide the personality. The conscious and unconscious elements act and function as one.
Learning, according to the human psycho-physiology is a combination of the conscious and unconscious processes.
In addition, according to the Human Psycho-Physiology, both the conscious and the emotional elements are essential for any change to occur.
Self Directed Learning is the type of learning in which the individual selects his / her own learning objectives, designs his / her own curriculum and creates his / her own learning environment and pace. As the conscious and unconscious elements are involved, in addition to the conscious and unconscious processes, the learner is involved in self assessment and correction.
Self Directed Learning System in a nutshell: Self Directed Learning is the type of learning in which the individual selects his / her own learning objectives, creates his / her own curriculum and designs his / her own learning pace and environment.
HPLS – an Internet Based Self-Directed Learning System
HPLS is the High Performance Learning System, which is an Internet Based Learning Environment, that provides an educational system for self directed learning.
HPLS – Self Directed Learning for the Concept-oriented Learning System
HPLS is a Concept-oriented Learning System that provides the learner with self directed learning system. The self directed learning system of the HPLS allows the learner to learn at his / her own pace.
Concept-oriented Learning System of HPLS Self directed learning system at the same time provides the learner with all the benefits of the concept-oriented educational system. Concept-oriented learning system of HPLS, adapts the learner’s own learning environment and the learning pace. In addition, it provides a very efficient learning environment which involves both learning and performance. As the learning, in the HPLS, is the process of discovering, constructing, and redefining facts, principles and concepts, the learner is able to create and utilize his / her own learning methods and ways of learning.
High Performance Learning Inc., (HPL Inc.) is an educational services organization in Canada. It provides its services to the international organizations, educational institutions and to the individuals for the purpose of learning and teaching.
HPL Inc. is owned and run by Suresh Singh who is the Director and the CEO of HPL Inc. The HPL is the company’s major research and development projects.
HPL Inc. also offers a range of educational courses and consultancy services.
HPL Inc. is committed to the concepts and principles of research and development.
For further details on HPL Inc, click here: http://www.highperformancelsi.com/
HPL’s History:
HPL Inc, High Performance Learning Inc., is an educational services organization and was established in 1990 in Canada. The High Performance Learning System, HPLS, was designed by Suresh Singh in 1990. The High Performance Learning System is an adaptive interactive personalized learning system that is based on self directed learning. Since 1990, Suresh Singh has devoted himself to the HPLS. The HPLS is his major research and development project for the past 12 years. During this period, Suresh has collected data from more than 70 students. He has studied their learning behavior, their performance, and has provided counseling, and psychological guidelines for their further improvement in their learning and performance. This has given him and also the learners, valuable feedbacks which enhanced Suresh’s knowledge and HPLS. His own experience and the feedbacks from the learners has provided Suresh the understanding and experience about the Self Directed Learning. Suresh Singh has also participated in numerous educational seminars, conferences and workshops about learning and teaching. He has written many articles, pamphlets and books about the self directed learning. Suresh Singh has been the President of ACCESS-LEARN, Association for Canadian College English Language Academies, and has participated in many international academic conferences. Suresh is also the founder and CEO of HPL Inc.
HPL’s Vision:
The vision of High Performance Learning System, HPLS, is to provide an individualized learning and educational system for the self directed learning.
HPL’s Philosophy:
The philosophy of HPLS is to provide the education and learning based on the Self-Directed learning (SDL). This philosophy is based on Suresh Singh’s study of the Learning and Performance based on the researches, the studies, and the applications. Suresh Singh believes that the HPLS provides the best technology for the concept-oriented learning.

Home/Medicine and Health/What do a doctor, nurse and medical researcher do?
The first person we turn to with our health concerns is a General Practitioner (GP). We turn to medical researchers for treatments of new health concerns. In the second group are nurses.
Ask a ­Doctor
Ideas for Writing About Health Science

You're a nurse a few days after starting your job. It's been eight hours of hard work, and your shift just started back at eight o'clock. A doctor enters the room and announces that a patient's condition has suddenly worsened. You know how to administer most of the treatments given to this patient. But you've never dealt with this problem before. Your patient is a young teenager on bedrest with an illness that can sometimes cause the patient's heart to go out of rhythm. You've never seen this sort of heart problem before.
The doctor tells you he thinks something is wrong with the patient's heart -- that he has a problem called "sick sinus syndrome." You're given no treatment plan, but the doctor asks you to continue everything you are doing and administer medicines as usual. The patient's heart rate seems to improve slightly. Meanwhile, the patient's blood pressure and breathing become more labored than normal. Your patient continues to become more and more confused and unable to focus.
"Is she okay?" you ask, worried about the patient's condition. You tell the doctor what the patient is saying. He leaves his office but returns immediately. "It's called 'electrical storms,'" he replies, as he begins to write the chart. "We'll give her more medication for the heart arrhythmia. This is a known side effect of a low blood pressure. But what can we do about the confusion and the disorientation?"
During the next few hours, the doctor and a pharmacist confer together. The patient is given medications that are in the pharmacist's "recipe book." As she takes the medication, her heart rate returns to normal. But she's still disoriented and not improving. The doctor orders some more tests to determine what is causing the disorientation.
After five more hours of work and more medications, the patient's condition becomes worse rather than better. "Damn," the doctor says with frustration. Your patient becomes more and more confused, and breathing becomes increasingly difficult. You wonder if the patient will live through the rest of this shift. You watch as the patient's eyeballs begin to roll to the side of her head. The doctor tries to do something, but you're not sure what. The doctor calls for his team.
Sitting in a chair beside the patient, you look up at the doctor and ask if her blood pressure and heart rate can be normalized. She's still not responding, although her blood pressure and heart rate are higher than they've ever been. "Damn," the doctor says. The doctor looks at the patient's chart and orders more tests. Then an EKG arrives; a nurse puts the electrodes on your patient. Blood is drawn for tests.
Nurses in hospitals, private offices, and clinics are trained to do important tasks in the medical environment.
Your patient wakes up but is still confused. Her disorientation and difficulty breathing do not improve. But her blood pressure is fine, and her heart rate is also within a normal range. What on earth is going on? The doctor orders tests for thyroid conditions, diabetes, and even brain tumors. The doctor gives your patient a sedative to put her to sleep. An endoscopy -- a procedure in which a doctor looks inside the patient's body -- confirms that there are no problems in the patient's throat. Then the doctor announces that the patient's body and breathing seem to be responding well to her sleep.
The doctor then decides that your patient may be having "hypoglycemic episodes," a sudden drop in blood glucose that can occur in diabetics. He orders the patient's blood to be continuously tested for the level of sugar. After a few hours, glucose levels seem to be increasing. But the patient's confusion and disorientation do not improve.
You watch as the nurse gives some medication that is supposed to raise the patient's sugar level. She calls for help as your patient's breathing becomes labored. Her oxygen level drops below the normal level for 10 seconds, and she's losing consciousness. Her heart rate is also below what's normal. Dozens of doctors and nurses enter the room with the EKG machine, looking for answers. The patient's blood sugar level is below the normal level again. Her heart rate increases just enough to register correctly again. But her breathing becomes more difficult.
You stand frozen outside the patient's room. Your mind is a jumble of questions and answers. You know that some of the medications given to your patient could cause problems within the patient's body. But what exactly is causing these problems?
You look at the patient's chart, which has now been turned into a disorganized mess. Her blood pressure, weight, sugar level, and heart rate have been written over and over on it. But where these numbers are written becomes confusing and hard to follow. Even the doctor's notes are a jumble of ideas: "Possible hypothyroidism," "Possible diabetes," "Possible brain tumor," "Possible low-dose aspirin," "Possible allergies."
An hour later, the patient is awake, but her head is moving erratically. The doctor calls for another sedative. The drugs given to your patient can be addictive. It is unlikely that she will be given a good sleep-inducing medication. But the doctor wants your patient to be quiet and asleep so he can continue trying to figure out what's wrong with her. The doctor suggests that it's more likely that your patient is suffering from "sleep-deprivation." But she does not respond to sleep-promoting medications.
The doctor takes his time evaluating the patient's situation. Then he places several electrodes on his hands and asks the nurse to attach them to the patient: "He's asleep! Let's get these electrodes off real quick and ask all the doctors to discuss what we're seeing."
The doctor takes you aside and tells you to stop talking to doctors or nurses about the patient. After the conversation, you ask why he wants you to stop talking to the doctors. "I don't trust what's written on the chart yet," he replies. "I won't believe it until I see what we do with the patient."
You go back to the patient's room. She's staring at the ceiling. She moves her mouth, trying to speak and struggling to focus. You ask her to lie still and not say anything. She smiles at you, nods, and closes her eyes. Then she closes and opens them again.
You walk over to the patient's bed and lean in close to see her better. You can see her eyeballs moving. You wonder what could be blocking the electric pathway between her brain and her eyes. "She's not getting enough oxygen or she is losing too much oxygen," a doctor says, looking at the patient on a computer screen connected to the patient by a ventilator. "Is there a problem with the ventilator?"
Your patient is a real person with her own body. You're in her room, and you listen as doctors discuss their theories. How did you get here?
When my mother had a heart condition when she was young in the 1970s, a doctor prescribed a drug to lower her blood pressure but warned my mother of several side effects that could occur. She told my mother that she might develop headaches and dizziness, for example. But she had no symptoms, so there was no reason to assume the drug was causing these problems. My mother didn't ask many questions about the drug, though, because she was being treated at a top hospital.
"The doctor's always right," she said to me. "You should always listen to your doctor." Her doctor knew what was best, so she didn't question him. In turn, I never questioned any doctors I saw. Although I always had questions about what I was experiencing, how I was recovering from surgery, and how long I needed to be on medications, I didn't question any doctors or treatment plans.
My mother grew tired of doctors as the years passed, so when I called to ask questions, she'd tell me to "go talk to your doctor." But I only rarely went to see doctors. In 2001, for example, I had to undergo two surgeries for two different problems with my heart -- anemia and an irregular heartbeat. During the first operation, I lost an immense amount of blood because of clotting issues. This led to anemia and another surgery to have blood transfusions.
Then, in 2003, I developed another problem with my heart involving irregular palpitations. Every few years, I'd start noticing that my heart was racing -- so fast that I was having trouble breathing and I'd pass out.
When I first noticed that I was having these "palpitations," the people at work suggested that if I wanted to stop feeling the sudden heartbeats, I should stop smoking -- just as people often advised my mother to quit smoking when she was having a problem with her heart. But smoking was not the problem.
After being sent home from work with palpitations in April 2003, I went to see two different cardiologists in New York City. They both ordered tests and told me to prepare for another surgery. "You're having heart tests," they both told me. The cardiologists advised me to "quit anything that will make my heart work harder."
The tests were all done, and I was told I could stop the tests and go home the next day. Then I started to notice my heart speeding up again. I was advised that my heart was probably healing from my last surgery in 2001. I had lost over 10 pounds after my second surgery, so when I started gaining back that weight and eating red meat, I was told I should stop -- even though I'd been a vegetarian for four years. "I need to talk to someone about the medication I'm taking for my heart," I told them. "It's making my heart beat fast." The cardiologists thought I should just stop taking one of the medications, so I wasn't told I had to undergo any more tests before my medications were changed or stopped altogether.
Since then, I've started taking medication with more active ingredients -- medication that's more likely to "trigger" problems rather than prevent them. So nowadays, I take my heart medicine and forget about its side effects.
But I still don't ask questions. In fact, I don't believe what I really think. I still believe in the doctors. When things go wrong, I don't think there are any mistakes made. When I was 16 years old and was having abdominal pain and not going to toilet, my mother told me I needed an ultrasound. "I'll see your doctor in three weeks," she told the doctor in his office. "In three weeks, I'll know what's wrong with you and I'll be back to see you."
The doctor told her that an ultrasound was not necessary, since I had eaten something new, which was probably blocking my intestines. "Go home and keep eating the same foods you've always eaten," he said. But my mother disagreed with him, so she kept me off that kind of food.
I saw the doctor three weeks later, and by then my abdominal pains were so extreme that I was having to stay awake in a chair in the family room while my mother slept in the bedroom. My mother wanted me to "go under the doctor's care" again if the problem was still bothering me. So I went to the bathroom and told my mother I needed to go and would be back. But I never came back, so she followed me to the bathroom down the hall. I couldn't move. The pressure was so immense that I had to sit still and not move, or I would have to rush to the bathroom. I was having difficulty breathing and speaking.
My mother asked me if I needed a doctor or if I was "okay." I told her that I hadn't finished. She got scared when I told her how I felt -- how I "couldn't move." I'd never told her what it felt like for me to be constipated like that. My mother called the doctor immediately.
And that was my third or fourth "appointment" with the doctor. I was only 16 years old, and I could not have left the living room because the pressure on my abdomen was so intense. I didn't understand that my mother wasn't listening to me. I didn't understand that the doctor wasn't listening to my mother. I knew that something was wrong, but I always believed what the doctor told me.
In the operating room, I had a "surgery" on my stomach to "fix" the problem. The doctor told my mother that I needed an incision in my stomach for another "operation." "It will be a minor operation," he told her, even though he was "putting me to sleep."
I had another surgery on my colon when my mother saw something on the endoscopy exam that looked like a "strangulating blood clot." I was diagnosed with diverticulitis.
But I still don't question doctors. In fact, I rarely leave them and rarely see any of them again. When I do go to a doctor, I simply get the information I need. And if I don't ask when I have questions, I don't get any information. If I don't ask, "Can you tell me what my medications are for?" then I'll not know whether the medications I'm taking are helping me or are the cause of all the new problems that I'm having.
I'll not know if I have a problem that needs to be treated. I won't even know if I'm doing things that will help prevent and cure illnesses in a different area -- a different part of my body. I might ask questions like, "Will medications I take now stop my heart from beating fast?" And the doctor might answer, "We can't know for certain, but our medicine should be okay." But how will I know what I'm taking is actually working or that I will even be using medications for years and years to come without knowing how they're affecting the next area of my body? How can I ask doctors to explain their procedures and why they think their tests are right?
How can you find a job with the medical information technology and systems you will learn through these resources?
If you have a good grasp of math and the ability to work with computerized calculations, you will need to prepare for the job market by finding a school that will give you the training and practical experience you'll need not just in math but for working with computer programs as well. Here is a list of schools you can start with.
These schools are not affiliated with and/or cannot recommend any particular career path.
"Certification is offered through the National Healthcareer Association (NHA), Institute of Healthcare Administrators (IHCA) and the National Certification Board (NCB") -- the three NAMSS certifying bodies. The NHA and the IHCA are industry associations, whereas the NCB is a certification organization formed by NAMSS specifically to address the need for special industry certification. All employers have the right to determine who receives their approval for an NAMSS Certification. However, to be considered eligible for NAMSS Certification, you must have one year under your belt in medical billing and or/coding, have at least six months experience working in your chosen field and hold a high school diploma or GED. Both programs are considered equal to the Certification Exam offered by NAMSS.
Some of those who are looking for a career change -- like retirees -- might not need a certificate for the job search. In contrast, college-educated medical professionals will likely need some kind of certificate to land even an entry-level position. This means that finding a school that offers degrees as well as certificate programs is a must.
"The program's curriculum includes the following skills: healthcare delivery, health services and financial management, medical records, medical terminology, and medical billing. Certification is awarded to individuals who complete the program and pass the exam approved by the National Board.
"The average salary for an individual working in a medical records management position varies from $20,000 to $70,000. The average salary to be an executive with a bachelor's degree is between $70,000 and $100,000"
"The course provides an introduction to medical data processing and medical records management. It will cover medical record content, health records, legal aspects and HMO. The course also consists of medical record coding systems, the ICD code sets and insurance claim systems. It provides training in medical records management, as well as ICD coding and billing guidelines. Dear student. Thank you for your question. Please see my reply below.
The mockingbird is often associated with innocent, unassuming creatures that are vulnerable or powerless to protect themselves from harm. In the novel, the mockingbird symbolizes the values of equality, kindness, and innocence, as well as the idea that life is unfair. For example, the character Atticus Finch defends a Black man (Tom Robinson) who is wrongfully accused of rape and is convicted through a racist justice system. Atticus represents the true meaning of the mockingbird in the novel by standing up for what is right and fighting for what he believes in, even when it seems impossible to win. The mockingbird is a symbol of the values that are at the heart of the novel and is a reminder that these values are threatened by unjust and unfair practices in society.
The mockingbird also represents the themes of the novel, such as racism, inequality, and injustice. The character Atticus Finch is a representation of the values that the mockingbird stands for, and his actions in defending the victim against the unfair justice system are a representation of the character’s beliefs. Furthermore, the injustice that Tom Robinson faces shows how racism and inequality can lead to unfairness and unjust practices in society, which reflects the themes of the novel.
In summary, the mockingbird in the novel is a symbol of the values that the characters represent and is a metaphor for their struggles and the struggles of society against the injustice that they face. The theme of the novel is highlighted as an important element that helps to illustrate themes and events throughout the course of the story. In short, I think that the mockingbird is a powerful symbol in the novel that is used to convey the themes and events that are central to the story. I hope this was helpful to you! s Won’t Hunt! When my father took me for a ride in his helicopter, I was just 15 years old. This was in the year 1972, when the Indo- Pak war was at its peak. We were flying from Amritsar in Northern India to Srinagar, the capital of Pakistan-occupied Kashmir, (called PoK). I was excited to fly in a helicopter for the first time.
The weather was very cool, as the nights in that region were usually cold. Since this was a military helicopter, no permission was needed from the Civil Aviation Authority in India to fly. No one seemed to notice us as our helicopter took off and then flew through the dark sky. As we came close to Srinagar, lights below started appearing like a bunch of jewels, shining in the night. Soon after we landed in Srinagar, we were escorted to a hotel by some soldiers.
Then we started the business part of our trip. The helicopter picked up about 50 of us in the city of Srinagar, and flew us to PoK, and dropped us in a very remote area near the border with Punjab. When I looked out of the aircraft, I saw a large mountain range looming in front of me. We were in for a wild night, and a very cold one. In the morning we started moving over the snow covered mountain trail. But because it was summer, that meant there were no heavy snowdrifts.
The only risk was crossing crevasses that were filled with snow, which would make our journey dangerous. As we moved forward, suddenly, the Pakistani army helicopters arrived, led by the famous General Akbar, and also some Indian troops. The air combat started when their helicopter tried to forcefully bring us down. They were firing from one side, and then, two F16 fighter jets came in and attacked us from the other end. All of a sudden their aircraft disappeared in a cloud of smoke as the two combatants exchanged shots.
Then as we started moving, an Indian jet came out of nowhere and scrambled us. The next day, we returned, and this was all it cost us: one fighter jet from the Indian side, one F16 from the Pakistani, and one helicopter each. I was really scared when I saw that the helicopter, into which my father and I were travelling, had a hole in its tail, which was caused by our own jets. No one was injured, as we managed to get out before anything happened.
In spite of such a scary experience, I enjoyed it so much. My father gave me the nickname of “Won’t Hunt!” whenever I travelled with him. It was just another day in a life that I love so much. “House of Commons”. Source. https://www.gov.uk/government/groups/house-of-commons-committees. All Rights Reserved. The House of Commons, also known as Westminster, is the lower house of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, with members chosen through an election held every five years.
To be a member of the UK Parliament, you need to be 18 years old, a British citizen and on the electoral roll. Only this time, I will let her decide. The House meets on a daily basis during the week at the Palace of Westminster in London, but meetings are less frequent during August.
Parliament is also in session during the recess. Committees form part of the process of creating a law. Most committee work is done in private. The Public Bills Committee of each of Parliament’s Houses considers bills, and makes recommendations on their final form.
Committees also review legislation prepared by Government ministries. A Speaker, a Deputy Speaker and a Parliamentary Clerk represent the House of Commons of the UK, and serve as its chief administrative officer. It is possible to have committee meetings away from the Palace of Westminster. For example, the House of Commons Committees on Climate Change and on the Digital Economy, meet in Portcullis House – adjacent to Westminster.
Committee business is governed by Standing Orders – or the formal rules of procedure – of the UK Parliament. Parliamentary Committees help Members to exercise scrutiny and oversight. For example, they review the impact of legislation on specific parts of society, the economy and the environment. Most committees will examine a draft bill before it is introduced in the House of Commons, and will discuss its likely success once it has passed through Parliament.
Parliamentary committees are also involved in scrutinising Government departments and other bodies, including the BBC. For more information on committees, see parliamentary. uk/about/how/mpsandlords.html. You can also find a list of current committee members on the same website. Parliament’s business is largely organised to enable MPs to be represented on a committee.
However, Members may only participate in two committees at a time. According to Standing Orders, a committee has 20 members and its size is determined by the composition of the House of Commons. It must have 11 MPs from the House of Commons, and 9 from the House of Lords.
A “majority party” is the party with the most members. The Government’s parliamentary strategy is not the same for all committees, and the role of minor parliamentary parties is not so obvious in the UK. To be a member of a committee, you must be a member of the House of Commons.
The number of committee members is proportional to the size of the House, and committee membership is proportional to the size of the parties, so committee membership is proportional to the major parties. There is no set ratio between committee members from each party.
As a member of the House of Commons, you may seek to serve on an official parliamentary committee, or on a committee of an official party, or in a private committee. Standards in public life are considered by Parliamentary Committees, and in 2007 a joint committee of the House of Commons and of the House of Lords established the standards in public life review process which established the basis for current principles of public life. The Code of Conduct of Members of the House of Commons is based on these principles, but members are not obliged to observe them if they wish.
The Code of Conduct is used as the basis of a member expenses scandal in 2009, which led to a parliamentary enquiry that resulted in the establishment of a parliamentary watchdog. In 2014, the report of the committee on privileges, published in the Daily Mail, concluded that a parliamentary “code of conduct” should be set up for MPs to ensure that their financial interests are properly managed and declared. In 2016, a parliamentary committee of the House of Commons concluded that a parliamentary code of conduct would not have prevented the “Expenses scandal”. The report concluded that a voluntary code would have “a profound effect on the public’s perception of MPs, and would inevitably have a significant negative impact on relations between the House and the House of Lords”.

APS OF VIDS MANNERS BY MANNING PODCASTS/RADIO/TELEVISION EPISODES RSS FEED READING ARTICLES WRITTEN BY US
This piece was commissioned by the UCL Art Museum and the UCL Art Gallery.
1. All that is solid melts into air by the artists Aaron Bastani and Andrew Goffey, 2009, collection: UCL. 1756 is the year when the famous novel Gulliver’s Travels by Johnathan Swift was published. 2. Fragments of Dreams by Zahid Mubarak, 2004, collection: UCL. The collection of UCL Art Museum consists of a few hundred artworks. 3. The Caterpillar and Butterfly, 2013, collection: UCL Art Museum The exhibition I’m working with is a project titled The World is Flat, The Earth is Squashed, which has been developed by a collective called NUAC. The exhibition opens with an installation by Gareth Cadwallader called The Caterpillar and the Butterfly, in which there is a giant caterpillar which turns itself into a butterfly. It’s a surreal experience when you are in it, which is part of why I like the piece so much. When I visited the exhibition and was in the butterfly, I could feel the pressure and the weight of the butterfly, which gave the feeling of a struggle of trying to become a human being. But, because it is a butterfly and light and airy at the same time, the message came across of trying to be free as humans are in some respects, trying to find a way to break free from things that are holding us down. The piece relates to what Swift said in his writings and the essence of 1756 is that the world is in a state of chaos. Also a lot of the exhibition refers to the chaotic times we are living through
with Trump coming into power and Brexit, which relates to 1756. 4. I Am Not A Bird, 2018, collection: NUAC The title of the exhibition, The World is Flat, The Earth is Squashed, comes from the book I Am Not A Bird by Aaron Bastani and Andrew Goffey. It is a book which features in the exhibition and refers to the chaotic times we are living in. I have chosen to use the exhibition for the basis of this project because I was captivated by the messages it was putting out and how it related to the chaotic times we live in. I was very excited to work with an exhibition about which I already knew so much because I am fascinated by the themes that relate to the times we live in and the themes in the work. 5. 100 Things Wrong with Society Today, 2018, collection: NUAC The book I Am Not A Bird is about creating a better version of society, where women can be equal to men and people can treat each other with more respect. The project is based on the themes in the exhibition and in 100 Things Wrong With Society Now, which the artists refer to in the book I Am Not A Bird. One hundred things that are the cause of problems in society today and how to solve them. These are things
like mental health, LGBTQ+ issues, politics, and more. Another work in the book and the exhibition which I chose is The Caterpillar and the Butterfly, by Gareth Cadwallader. In The Caterpillar and the Butterfly, the butterfly is an all-seeing, all-knowing thing which observes all that is around it and it learns so much. I found this fascinating and it’s one of his concepts that resonates with me. I want to work on creating something that takes into account the themes I mentioned before and the feelings expressed by the artists. I also think the artists are very interested in the idea of art and how it can bring about a lot of change in society. 6. Gulliver as a child, 2014, collection: UCL Art Museum As with a lot of museum exhibitions, the exhibition does use a lot of traditional painting methods, which I found interesting. I want to use oil painting to explore this and see how I can create something which is a painting that looks like a painting but also a contemporary work of art which is also a modern-day painting. If we see the book from the perspective of a work of art, what elements of traditional art do we see in the book, such as composition, shapes and colours? I wanted to work on making these things more traditional to create a painting related to the themes in the book, I Am Not A Bird. I also want to create something which is a painting and at the same
time a contemporary work of art. The work would be about the themes mentioned before and also the chaotic times we live in at the moment. I chose to work on painting because I believe it gives the artwork an old-fashioned, classical feel, which then relates it to the classical times we often read about and the works created by authors in those times. 7. Gulliver in the Lilliputian Lands by Samuel Scott, 1726, collection: UCL Art Museum I wanted to try and create a painting that makes people feel like they are in the painting at the same time as making them question what it is they are seeing. I think the painting also has an element of storytelling which is interesting to explore and is related to the theme in I Am Not A Bird that storytelling is so important and how it can bring people closer together. The painting is also very traditional and I like using traditional means to make something contemporary at the same time. The painting is also about social injustice and I think, by combining all these elements in one painting, I can create something that is very relevant to society at the moment and the times we live in. 8. Gulliver as a giant, 2008, collection: UCL Art Museum Another work I want to look at creating a work of art about is Gulliver in the Lilliputian Lands by Samuel Scott. In the book and in the exhibition, there is a lot of discussion about different societies, the different peoples of the world, and what things make a civilised society. A lot of
discussion is around money and poverty levels and it makes you question whether a wealthy society necessarily needs to be a socially stable one. We live in a time when poverty levels are increasing and there are more people in dire circumstances, especially in the UK, yet there is lots of emphasis on wealth and people who have the most money being seen as the most successful. This relates to the themes in I Am Not A Bird and I want to create something that makes people question their assumptions on what is actually important. 9. Gulliver arrives in Lilliput, 1870, collection: UCL Art Museum Gulliver as a giant in the exhibition has an interesting element of reality which intrigues me so much, so this leads me to something the artists in the exhibition are also interested in, which in the book and in the exhibition, is a society which makes it possible for it to function. Many of the things in society are actually quite simple to imagine. If there was no war, if people had a better understanding of each other, and a lot of other things, there would be a more justifiable society. I want to create something which imagines this and to do so with a traditional element which is linked to the times we live in and the exhibition. There is so much discussion about the idea of society. It’s strange how it’s really not that complicated to imagine if everyone was equal and people actually took the time to really get to know each other. I am interested in creating something that really reflects what society is telling us
to think and to imagine and to really encourage people to really think outside of the box which they are often told to do. 10. Gareth Cadwallader and Aaron Bastani
11. The Mothers Day painting, 2013, collection: NUAC A painting which is also in the exhibition I am really interested in is The Mothers Day painting by Gareth Cadwallader. It explores the themes of social media and technology. It is called selfies, a new word for self-portraits, which I think is super interesting and relevant to the chaotic times we live in. There are so many debates about what we should and shouldn’t say, or how we should behave, especially on social media. The artist also refers to other artists like Andy Warhol and Duchamp, which I am also interested in examining, as well as making my own ideas about how society can also be reflected in art. The painting references the 1960s, the beginning of the ‘new age of technology’ and the emerging trends of modern culture, so to think about these in the context of our own lives today and their implications is something that fascinates me. It is about the notion of people taking selfies every day, in the same way, for example, they post on Instagram, showing off the things they have bought and worn. This brings to the surface the idea that we show off social media and social media tells us what we should be wearing and what we should be doing every day. I am interested in how selfies relate to our contemporary world. This painting references these themes and
the idea of how these things relate to the classical world and the classical period of time when these authors wrote. I want to find new ways to explore these themes and concepts. 12. Sculpture I Am Not A Bird, 2015, collection: NUAC My work would be based on these themes and also create something that is made in the classical
way. It would have something traditional to do with it, like a still life painting, which I think represents reality. The piece reflects society and the issues that there are to deal with in a classical way, and also I want to make it feel contemporary. My work would be in a sense contemporary and not traditional and reflect current trends and ideas in a classical way. I will be creating a classical painting in the style of a still life painting which will include other items, such as a piece of metal with the words ‘Love is not a business’ printed on it. I think it would be really interesting to explore this classic style of painting, but with an item which is used in our society today and which speaks about our love life and social media. 13. Video art, 2009, collection: UCL Art Museum The title of this piece, The Caterpillar and the Butterfly, relates to the idea that you have to go through suffering before you can become something and that there are struggles that we have to go through to ultimately create something better. The piece represents the chaotic times we are living in. The chaos is a feeling which is almost a physical feeling in our time, but I don’t think people recognise quite how much that is the case. We have to recognise and empathise with our feelings
at a time when there are chaotic circumstances to deal with. I think it will be really interesting to create something which relates to this piece. Another piece which has elements that relate to the things I want to put into my painting is one by Andrew Goffey, called Fragments of Dreams. It is about a man sleeping and his dreams and what it means to be human. It is a painting which represents a lot of the ideas in the exhibition about being human which I am interested in and want to explore. The painting is about a dream and is about the themes of sleep and insomnia. It also brings to light the struggle of being human, and that struggle can be found in different ways, through music, through paintings, and in other artworks. I think it is really fascinating to try and express what it means to be human and what that involves. My work would want to explore the struggle that comes through the modern world, but also our emotions. 14. Lecture by Gareth Cadwallader, 2017, collection: NUAC One event in the exhibition which I think is really important is a series of lectures which have been organised about different social issues by Gareth Cadwallader. There was a lecture about poverty, a lecture about the environment, a lecture about LGBTQ+ issues and the struggle women face. I want to explore these and create something that is based on these lectures. They are so important to society and really highlight the importance of trying to change society for the better.
Gareth is a fantastic lecturer and I think his lectures are really important to explore. I want to create something that focuses on these issues and really brings to life the chaos we face, the chaos of trying to survive with so many other people on the planet. It could be something which really brings to life the struggle that people feel through the modern world. I am interested in creating something that expresses these feelings and which then expresses the issues in the book I Am Not A Bird. Hopefully it will really encourage people to think about how society operates. The book is about the chaos of trying to change social injustices in society. It’s a reflection of the chaos in which we live and the chaotic times we live in. 15. The book Gulliver's Travels is 1756, collection: UCL Art Museum One thing I am inspired by in the exhibition is how it is all about the book Gulliver’s Travels which is interesting to explore. The book is the focus of the exhibition and the focus of my work, which is quite something I think, because it often happens that contemporary work isn’t about classical texts. In exploring classical texts and the themes of the book, Gulliver’s Travels, and how they relate to the chaotic times we live in, I also want to explore if we can do anything to change these things, and if we can create change from something which is related to classical times. In creating something that has a modern
appeal to it, it makes sense to start with what is classical. I think something that is interesting about this is that a lot of the themes are still the same, they can be seen in today’s society. In the times when these writers wrote, all their thoughts and observations were related to the society we saw throughout that time. We still have so many of the same issues today and it’s fascinating to explore how these writers captured such similar feelings. 16. The exhibition uses books that are related to the exhibition Aaron Bastani and Gareth Cadwallader, 2018, collection: UCL Art Museum It’s not just the book that is of interest to me. I am very interested in the works of these incredibly clever and intelligent minds that they have created and I want to explore how I can create something that tries to relate to this in a contemporary way. They create artworks and these pieces of work really interest me, because I want to explore in my own artwork how can I create something that tries to relate to the feelings and thoughts of an artist. I want to explore how to create something that is classically based which can also have something modern about it and relate to what happens now in the world. 17. Gulliver, The Artist, 2019, collection: NUAC One of the works I am thinking about creating is a piece inspired by the book I Am Not A Bird, which is about Gulliver. The book and the exhibition is about the exploration of people and their feelings and how
they see what is going on and the difficulties they have. It’s about how people see and understand each other and how we can improve our feelings. There is the idea of love, and I think that concept that it is all connected to the idea of trying to see ourselves in relation to our feelings and what we are doing. It’s about how we see ourselves in relation to other people and other things. I want to try and think from the perspective of Gulliver who is Gulliver, the artist and Gulliver as the artist, as well as Gulliver as a person and a character in a book. I am not sure quite what style to use in this work, but I want to try and create an image of Gulliver which shows him as an artist. There is the idea of Gulliver painting himself. How did he see himself as a person and what role did he play in the artwork, how did it change over the story? It is about how people are connected to this story and to Gulliver as a person and how we see people as people. I think it would be really interesting to explore one of my main questions of how we look at art, how it affects us, and how we feel when we look at art. These questions are things I want to explore myself with the exhibition and my own work. Art is so often about the way that people feel and it is one of the most important things about art. I am interested in how I am going to show and express that. It is also an interesting question because sometimes there are many kinds of art and you can’t always define precisely what something is and where it sits.
Low income housing 27 28 2 Lizzie Clarke
The concept of home is central to being human. In 2019 we have an unprecedented housing crisis, and low income housing is especially important to addressing the shortcomings of this. Unfortunately, there’s a lot of uncertainty around how far ‘low income housing’ should go. Should it be reserved for homeless and at risk of homelessness people? And if so, should this be managed entirely through the state? In the UK, as of March 2017 we have 630,000 homeless people and more than 1 million more in danger of losing their homes. In a time of great change and uncertainty, it can be stressful in our own lives to consider how we would have made a more secure choice, given the knowledge and resources available to us today. How do we ensure our right to a home for ourselves from the start? This essay argues that in tackling the problem from the beginning, we can make better choices, with more options and choices.
