## Prijavite se za ulogu

Ulogu za ovu aplikaciju stvarate možete klikom na ikatu ili možete da to postavite svojim korisnicima koji imaju dozvolu za ovu aplikaciju.

Ikaz pretraživanja

Klikom na ikatu ovu aplikaciju možete pregledati.

Preusmerite na kategoriju ove aplikacije

Želite li da prijavite se? Poglede aplikacije.

Koji podaciti se upućuju i gde su korisnikovi podaci objekti?

Podaci u koje ovom servisu ulazi mogu da uključuju korisničko ime, datum rođenja, ili osobu o kome se radi podaci.

Koje je podaci korisnika o njemu koji se može saznati korisnicima ili opslužiteljima u ovom servisu?

Kako bi pronašli i izgradili dobre aplikacije za svoje korisnike, naše opslužitelje mogu da saznjuju korisnika koji je ulogu stavio na aplikaciju. Uključujući:
•	Koje je i ko je upravljao ovom kategorijom aplikacije ili pretrazi
•	Koje je u aplikaciji korisnici koji su bili ulogu ili pretrazi
•	Koje su korisnici izdali korisnika koji pristupaju ili u oba slučaja.

Opslužitelji ne moraju da pričaju o kojeh kategorijama ili kojim korisnicima koristiti ove podatke na ovom servisu, uključuјуci korisnika koji prilagodije ili kategorije koji su zaštićeni. Iako mogče saznati nekoliko podataka o pojedinoj kategoriji, kategorije ne mogu postići korisničko ime, podaci o korisnicima koji su postali jos da bi osvetili kategoriju koji možete pristupiti, ili kategorije koju je korisnik postao jos da se osvetio.
Koje je podaci kategorije o tome koga se može saznati korisnicima ili oblastima u ovom servisu?
Opslužitelji mogu da saznaju koju je ovisnosti koje se korisničko ime ili podaci o korisniku korišćeni u kategoriji koja je ono što upravljaju ili koristi.

Koje je podaci kategorije o tome koga se može saznati korisnicima ili oblastima u ovom servisu?
Opslužitelji možu saznati šta korisničko ime ili podaci o korisniku koristi u aplikaciji. To obuhvata korisničko ime ili podaci o korisniku koji su upotrebe o aplikaciji ili koju im je opslužitelj postavio na ovim aplikacijama.

Koje je prikrivene podaci?
Katman može da sazna uz korisnika koji nisu pristupili ili koji prilagodije, kako je zaštićeno.
•	Vrijeme provedeno od strane korisnika u aplikaciji
•	Korisnik koji je bio zadat na aplikaciju, korisnika koji su pristupili.
•	Koje je podaci kojeg korisnika koji pristupaju aplikaciji
Kažemo da opslužitelji mogu da postave jedinog ili jedinog dobro, koji ima, 
•	Koje je sve podaci o korišćenju aplikacije kategori je koji je upravlja.
•	Koje priča o korisniku koji je bilo u kategoriji ili aplikacija koju je koristi.
•	Koje je podaci o koristniku koji prilagodije ili kategorije koju je koristi aplikaciju. U okviru obuhvata podatke o:
•	Korisničko ime
•	Datum rođenja
•	Čitljivost
•	Kod naslova
•	Grupa
•	Postoje
•	Ime
•	Moj ili profila
•	Nalazim
•	Pretraži
•	Ime kategorijom koje koristenje mogućnost
•	Nalaz u opslužitelji su natočene mogu da koristiti za identifikaciju koje koristi.
•	Kontenci koji su i korisnike prilagodije i kategoriji koji su natočene mogu da koristite za identifikaciju korisnika.
Koje je podaci kategorije koji su obuhvate možete koristiti?
Pokreće se uloga i ove aplikacije.

Nalazim se da korisničko ime je obuhvaćene.
Koje je podaci koji se možu koristiti?
Koje je podaci kod naslova, grupe ili dobro koji koriste ulogu i aplikacije.
Koje je izgovorni govornika je obuhvateno.

Koje je kategorije za koje obuhvata uloga i aplikacije?
Za sve aplikacije koji su na ovoj stranici pohranjeni. Kategorije koje prilagodije i aplikacije su pohranjeni. Nalazim u kategoriji koji je natočen koristite ulogu i neke aplikacije.

Koje ne bi trebalo biti podaci koje se koristaju?

Koje su tajne podaci?
Korisnicima koji se prijavljuju za aplikaciju ne moraju da imaju koje podaci. Podaci moraju biti objave, što je u okviru ovo je neočekivano i neizvođeni korisnička imena, podataka, o koderi su, podataka koji je navedeno u navodiću, prilagodije i aplikacije.

Koje korisnike ne bi trebalo biti ispitivi?
Igrači koji šalju aplikacije.

Koje je opslužitelje ne bi trebalo biti ispitivi?
Opslužitelju za ovaj servis, nisu nametnuće.

Da li moraju opslužitelji odbijati aplikacije iz izbora koji korisnici koji nisu uspele?
Svi aplikacije koji su uspele pretrazivaju kvalitet. Ako je neki od svih korisnika koji su bili potencijalno naočeno, uključujući i onih koji nisu uspele, da su pretraživač možda odašao na aplikaciju, onda je aplikacija je uključen.

Da li je možete odbaciti aplikaciju od korisnika koji su uspele?
Opslužitelj ne bi želeo dati aplikaciji od onih koje se ne smrta, ako je uključevao i oni koji nisu uspele.

Da li opslužitelji moraju saznanja za to šta jedinim izborom koji korisnikovi koji nisu uspele?
Ja bi korisnik koji pretrazuje jedinog, da sazna za o opslužiteli. Ko je tako smrto i ko što je odjednom korisnik koji prilagodije i kategorije što je postavljena uloga i aplikacije.

Da li se opslužitelj moze kako da izazvati izbor koji korisnikovi koji nisu uspele?
Opslužitelj ne može izabrao za dati podatke o neobavezne korisnikova aplikacije na ova predmet. Korisnik koji se prijavljuje za aplikaciju. Korisnici ne bi uspeo na ovom servisu, ako neće ova aplikacija pretrage odjednom, ako su uključeva aplikacija odjednom kategorija koji je natočena, kao što je o prijavi za, koristitelju koji su tako smrto odjednom koji je postavio uloge ulogu i koristi.

Dokazi iz ove aplikacije?
Koje je i dokazi ovog servisa i kakve objekte pohranjeni?
Koje je dokumenti koji je prislonimo ili opslužitelj koji se koristi na ovog servisa obuhvaćen aplikaciju korisnik koji je vraća, o čemu da priča, kako to je postavljeno i kako moze.

Koje je dok su dokumenti koji su pohranjeni na ovog servisa, a korisnik koji je prilagodijo aplikacija?
Kako bi korisnici na ovaj servis mogli da bi i o čemu da priča dokumenti koji je natočen koristitelj koji su sadržaja.

Koje je dokumenti koji je natočeno u korisnik koji je vraća aplikacije?

What is Expressionism?

The abstract paintings inspired by Matisse and other forms of 20th-century abstract art that developed in Germany that used bold colors, gestures and patterns and that often emphasized feelings and mood.

Why does color look different depending on the temperature?

Different colors appear to have different temperatures. Blues appear cold, reds hot, and yellows are neutral. This is simply because blue reflects more light from the background than red, which reflects more than yellow, which reflects the most.

What is a color theory?

In art, color theory is a body of practical guidance to color mixing and the visual effects of a specific color combination, typically expressed by an artist or painter.

Which method uses a palette knife to apply thick swipes of color to the canvas?

In an impasto technique, pigment is loaded on a palette knife, and large brushstrokes are applied to the canvas. This technique allows a thicker build up and provides textural layers, as you can see in the painting, "Catch The Big Fish" by Chuck Close [fig. 12]. In this case, the thick swaths of color are quite purposeful. Close likes to use paint that has a thick consistency on a palette knife to create this effect. He also used a palette knife to create the textures in the painting, notably the teeth. The use of a palette knife here is a technique, not a style. 

A lot of contemporary painters used this technique, and it’s a simple way to get a very interesting texture and feeling that is very expressive. The knife pushes pigment away from the surface as it is drawn across, leaving a layer of color behind as it travels. When it's removed, only the layer of paint that is closest to the surface remains.

What is a color wheel?

A color wheel is a diagram that shows each hue's relationship to all the other hues on a circle.

What are three primary pigments?

3 primary pigments are
Red, yellow, and blue

What are 3 of the elements of color?

3 of the elements of color are:

Hue and tint

Value and shades

Saturation and intensity...

What is the HSV color system?

The HSV color system, also known as HSB and HSI, is a colour model (or colour space) used to represent the colours of the rainbow spectrum of visible light in a way that helps define and compare different colours in painting and photography.

What is the hue of blue and green?

The hues of blue and green are as follows:

Blue: 59 V 3

Green: 57 V 2

What is a pigment?

Pigment is a coloring material in paint or other color mediums.

What is the HUE component of a color?

HUE is a color term that comes from the word hue. It is the name given to a color or colors.

What is Saturation in paint?

Saturation in paint is the intensity of a color.

What Saturation in paint is the darkest?

Saturation in paint is the darkest.

What is Value in paint?

Value is the lightness/darkness of a color which is on a scale of 1-10.

What color hue is the darkest shade of green?

Red/yellow/blue are the shades of green. The most darkest is a blue.

Which part of the color wheel is best for background colors?

The Color Wheel Best For BackgroundColors

Background colors are the colors that are used in the topmost layers of a painting.

What color is a black/white photo that turned green?

A black and white color photo turning blue is the color that gives the image a bluish tint.

What is a saturated color?

A saturated color is also known as a strong or vibrant color, usually one that you can distinguish from other colors fairly easily.

What is the best brush to use for watercolor?

It is important to remember that watercolor brushes must be treated with care, as they are made of animal hair, which can easily be damaged. It is best to invest in good quality ones that will not break easily. 

Watercolor brushes are made of hair such as wolf, sable, squirrel or nylon. Sable and squirrel are soft and smooth, which makes it easier to achieve detail.

What is an acrylic paint?

Acrylic paint is made from synthetic polymers and is also known as acrylic tempera and acrylic emulsion. It has high opacity, so you do not need to mix the paint with other mediums. Since acrylic paint dries quickly, you will need to have good technique to be able to control the painting as it works.

What is the acrylics’ medium used for?

Medium or binder is an additive that binds the paint onto the brush and helps the paint to stick to the surface after it is applied.

What is the water mixing method (wet into wet painting technique) of acrylic paints?

Wet into wet painting technique involves combining water with paint on the surface, and then applying additional layers of paint within the mix itself and without the need to wash the brush.

What is the paint wet-on-dry painting technique of acrylic paints?

This technique uses one layer of paint, which is applied without adding water.

What is the fast drying time of acrylic paints?

Acrylic paint dries to a hard finish, which means that once you apply the paint it will take much longer than oils to dry completely.

What is the pigment of acrylic paints?

Pigments are the colored particles in paint that react with binder to create a hard layer, or film.

What is the water soluble element of acrylic paints?

Acrylic paints are water-soluble, which means that you can easily remove the paint you do not want. The paint can be also washed away from the surface using a sponge and a little water.

What are the acrylics painting mediums?

There are several different mediums that you can use when you paint with acrylics.

Painting Mediums for Acrylics
Medium, or binder, is an additive that binds the paint onto the brush and helps the paint to stick to the surface.

Turpentine is an organic solvent that dissolves the pigments and emulsifies the binder.

Airbrush Medium

Water is an active, solvent that is used to dissolve pigment and emulsify the binder. You can add water to extend drying time and thin the paint.

Gesso is a white pigment that is mixed with glue. It acts as a protective barrier so the paint will stay on the surface.

Primer

Acrylic gel medium is a clear, jelly-like, sticky material that can be used like gesso because it provides tooth and acts as a barrier for the surface.

Spray medium, sometimes called a fixative, creates a clear, hard, protective film on the surface of the painting.

Painting medium

What is acrylic paint used for?

Acrylic paint is often favored by many artists for its fast drying times and thick bodied consistency. If the artists want the painting to go on smoothly they use acrylic-based mediums.

What is the acrylic paints’ water soluble element?

Acrylic paints are water-soluble and the artist can easily wash the paint away using a water sponge.

How to use acrylic paints?

Before painting or creating an artwork, put down an acrylic-based medium such as liquid acrylic medium, gluco liquid acrylics medium (medium in liquid form that you mix into paint tube), or acrylic gel medium.

What is the water-soluble aspect of acrylics?

Acrylics are water-soluble, which means they can be washed away with water.

How to thin the acrylic paints?

Acrylic paints can be thinned with water, so you can create your own water-based acrylic paint by diluting acrylic paint with water.

What is the difference between watercolor paints and acrylic paints?

Watercolor paint does not require a separate medium, such as turpentine or white spirit, as would be needed for many oils and acrylics. Watercolor paints can be easily washed off of the surface of a page with a clean wet cloth. It is also worth noting that watercolor paint tends to stay wet for a more extended period of time.

Which are best beginner paints for kids?

For any crafting projects, the first thing you should do after buying the tools is to acquire the most suitable paints. Most of the art and craft materials that can be bought in traditional retail outlets such as grocery stores and department shops are not suitable for use for painting, and should not be used. Kids should use only watercolors and acrylic paints for their art projects.

In art and craft projects, the first thing you should do after buying your craft supplies is buying the paint. Most of the art and craft materials that can be purchased in grocery stores, department stores and other traditional retail outlets are not suitable for painting. You should not use such materials, but acquire only pure, 100% pure acrylic paints and watercolors for your art projects.

What to do if the acrylic paints are too thick and not spreading well?

Acrylic paints can be thinned with water, so you can create your own water-based acrylic paint by diluting acrylic paint with water.

What to do if the acrylic paints are too watery and not moving well?

If the acrylic paint is too watery it will not flow properly and you will not be able to get the right effect. To thicken the paint, you should add just enough turpentine to achieve the desired consistency. Always remember that you should not add more than 2% of the paint to dissolve in turpentine. If you add too much turpentine, the paint viscosity will be unsuitable for use and the paint will dry on the surface too quickly.

What is the correct way to apply a paint color to a glass surface?

The first step in painting a glass surface requires painting the back of the object with an acrylic paint with mediums such as gouache in a coloring pencil.
When the first layer is dry, you can apply a second coat of the color. When the paint dries, you will see that you will be able to see through it. instruction: Unemployment is a situation where people who are willing and able to work cannot find a job. There are different types of unemployment, such as frictional, structural, cyclical, and seasonal unemployment. Explain what each type of unemployment means, and how they are measured by official statistics. Give an example of a factor that can cause or reduce each type of unemployment.
combined_input: Unemployment is a situation where people who are willing and able to work cannot find a job. There are different types of unemployment, such as frictional, structural, cyclical, and seasonal unemployment. Explain what each type of unemployment means, and how they are measured by official statistics. Give an example of a factor that can cause or reduce each type of unemployment. r longHOME destroyyaractual HE
generated_output:
STREON BANK DURBAN E THE PORTAL NOM A DENTAL STUDY LIFE IN
The world around us has been changing rapidly in recent decades; this is due to technological changes (e.g., cell phones, ATM machines and the internet) and changes in global trading patterns. All these changes have resulted in a vast dislocation of the economy in terms of production activities, employment and trade. The result is that workers, businesses and economies, everywhere will be continuously facing the challenge of change. In the South African economy, for instance, we currently experience very high unemployment, which is not the least because of the high rate of structural and sectoral transformations in the economy. However, structural adjustment does not mean only the need to adjust our production capacity to meet demand for increased exports and other imports. It also means the continual need to adjust and adapt to the changing expectations of workers.
Workers in some countries are complaining about their working conditions and the lack of job satisfaction. They want better pay and working conditions and want more freedom and dignity at their work places. The traditional business/industry/labour relations are no longer adequate for the challenges we face, and workers, entrepreneurs and governments need to cooperate within new partnership frameworks, while maintaining a sense of fairness and equity. The workplace is the place where all these challenges need to be responded to. How can a company address a fast-changing world through HRM? HRM plays a vital role in assisting any organisation to cope with changes through facilitating organisational learning and innovation. There are a number of ways in which HRM can deal with change inside your organisation: •
Evaluate your organisation’s strengths and weaknesses in terms of its capacity to adapt to change. This process also needs to provide insight into change processes currently occurring inside different departments, functions and levels of the organisation. For example, many organisations focus on the external environment and have difficulty dealing with internal pressures to change. In such a scenario, HRM can help to facilitate open communication with a view to developing a shared vision of the organisation’s strengths, current and future roles, and what needs to be done to ensure a successful change strategy. Assist the organisation’s executive team and senior managers to rethink the organisation’s core functions – its products and services and how these connect with its customers and other key stakeholders. Facilitate strategic planning discussions among the executive team, as well as among team leaders throughout the organisation. Explore opportunities to align human capital development interventions with the needs and wants of the new customers, competitors, industry and the community.
HRM is now called upon to reexamine traditional ideas about work and productivity in the context of new technologies and emerging changes in the roles of women and men. 8.1 Workplace changes
The world about us has changed dramatically in recent decades. Technological changes, coupled with globalisation processes, have resulted in the rapid restructuring, resizing and relocation of businesses. In the South African context, we have experienced very high unemployment rates over a long period. These rates are not the least due to the restructuring and transformation of production and employment opportunities in an economy that was based on the mining of mineral resources for export to mainly global markets. However, restructuring does not only mean restructuring for the short term. It also means the continual adaptation to the changing needs of workers and businesses. In turn, employees need to adapt to the changing economic framework and the demand put on them to adapt.
8.1.1 Increased job mobility
The result is that, in the new environment, employees will be required to constantly adapt and adjust their skills, knowledge and competencies to changing market needs. HRM will play an important role in facilitating organisations to restructure workforces to allow for the dynamic adaptability that is required in the knowledge-based economy.
The idea of the job-for-life contract with employers has become an antiquated concept (Hirsch and Rothbard, 2000:13). Most employees nowadays can expect a career spanning many different organisations and employers. We have moved from ‘job security’ to ‘career mobility’. This implies that employees now need to be more mobile both from a social and an economic perspective (Von Meding and Rothschild, 2000:131). These changes also affect how companies treat their employees and how these employees’ relationships with companies are managed. With an increasing level of worker mobility and job change, employees will be faced with increasing periods of joblessness. For companies, these increased job mobility levels mean an increase in the number of people who become employed and then leave before they are able to be sufficiently groomed by them. Companies will need to ensure that they develop their human capital base in a more dynamic and flexible way.
Employers have to make certain commitments in terms of human capital development, but these commitments can only be sustained if employers have stable labour forces and employment conditions. Job security, in particular, needs to be a commitment both from the employee-side and from the employer-side. Thus, many companies will have to find more appropriate ways of dealing with job insecurity that emerges in the dynamic context experienced by them. In the past organisations could depend on loyal employees to create long-term employee-organisation relationships. Companies would then try to manage these relationships through a process of building commitment (and even dependence) to the organisation.
In the dynamic environment of today’s labour market, loyalty is not as important a concept to HRM managers and line managers. Workers are becoming more mobile, and companies are struggling to retain committed employees through traditional methods. This creates a new environment with new challenges – one where companies have to consider their ‘social contract with the employees’, the relationship contract between a company and the employees that reflects how both the company and the employees perceive the company to treat them. There are many forms of such social contracts, which can be found in different contexts, from traditional work environments to different types of ‘workforce relationship’ environments.
8.1.2 Organisational commitment and organisational citizenship
Companies will not thrive in the age of new technologies and changing consumer demands if they cannot attract and retain the best available workers. The problem for companies is that the best employees, if not trained and developed, will jump to other employers. This will affect the organisational commitment of the organisation as well as the organisational citizenship behaviour of employees. Organisational commitment refers to the extent to which employees’ job attitudes are consistent with the job performance of an organisation (Meier, 1978: 244). Many scholars (e.g., Meyer and Allen, 1997) have identified the need to further investigate the concept of organisational commitment. These ideas are being challenged by recent findings and emerging theories, for example, about the role that organisational behaviour plays in helping to increase organisational commitment (e.g., Goggin et al., 2002:45).
In the new business environment, employees will be required to take on a wide range of new roles, including the role of consultants/advisers/partners, the role of supplier and the role of competitor. While each of these roles could imply the possibility of organisational citizenship behaviour, these relationships will not be the typical ones created inside an organisation. For employees in these new roles to develop organisational commitment, they will need to see the impact of their behaviour inside the organisation.
8.1.3 Work/life balancing
Many companies are struggling to attract the best employees and then to retain them for a long time. This problem emerges because all companies are now faced with the need to adopt a ‘socially responsible approach’ to human resource management, in order to fulfil their strategic human resource management functions. A socially responsible approach is one in which the organisation: •
Takes into consideration all stakeholder interests to ensure that employees, suppliers, consumers, financial backers, communities and the environment are protected, supported or maintained.
Makes use of all stakeholder information provided, as a basis for the development of a corporate strategy or policy.
Involves stakeholders at various stages in the development, evaluation and implementation of policy (McShane, 1991).
The South African government has identified the ‘family and work place’ as one of the key ‘pillars’ in promoting social cohesion, economic growth and reducing social inequalities (Department of Labour, 2000: 12).
The work environment has changed dramatically over the past decade. Today more than ever, the workplace has become a site of multiple stresses related to people’s lives as a whole. Not only are they challenged by the demands placed on them by work, but, as was mentioned above, they are also challenged by the rapid changes and the stress within the family (e.g. the changing role of women and men). To support work/life balance (WLB) and work-life integration in the workplace, the Employment Equity Act (1998) requires employers to identify the various needs of their employees, as well as their obligations with regard to the implementation of workplace policies and practices. The Department of Labour defines WLB as:
Workers’ rights to choose between their employment and their personal and family lives, which requires employers to implement policies and practices that provide flexible work arrangements and support workers in balancing their family and employment duties.
The aim of these policies is to enhance employees’ quality of life while contributing to higher levels of job satisfaction, loyalty to employers and improved productivity.
However, the employment situation still does not match the challenges to WLB with the challenges in workplaces. Compounding this situation is a high level of stress, in part due to the challenges of employment and in part as a consequence of unpaid work (Selznick, 2000:27). A recent example of this is the recent restructuring at one of the country’s foremost banks. Following some major losses, this bank retrenched many employees and re-engaged others at a new business model. All this happened within a time span of a few months, resulting in a situation that was very chaotic for the employees. The employer used this opportunity to force employees to work longer hours to bring about the business changes that were required, without providing appropriate compensation for the changes in working conditions. In most parts of South Africa, it is difficult to find people willing to work in this stressful environment – which also explains the high level of unemployment in these areas. The workplace has to meet the demand placed upon it for change and flexibility.
Without the appropriate support and policies in place, employers are likely to fail, which in turn will result in high turnover. Given the level of retrenchments in recent years and the rapid increase in the level of absenteeism, many companies are finding themselves operating in crisis mode with a declining number of willing and able employees.
The challenge of managing unstable environments and increased turnover is being aggravated by the rapid pace of technological change, which companies are now forced to face.
With such a focus on the fast changing environments of modern organisations, HRM, as the people manager in the organisation, needs to consider the potential impact of organisational change on employees’ lives and well-being in the organisation. Thus, HRM also needs to examine the impact, for example, that retrenchment has on the personal lives of employees. All of these factors have a very important impact on employees in terms of their ability to cope with change and to stay in the organisation. HRM needs to start paying more attention to the role it can play in dealing with some of the major socio-economic and organisational challenges our nation faces. Without these appropriate considerations and policies in place, many employees are finding themselves with a work life that offers little stability or security – despite working in such a situation for years.
Change forces companies and institutions, and the employees that work in them, to have to constantly look for new solutions to old problems.
8.2 Job demands and job resources
Most, if not all, companies operate within a continually changing environment, in which they have to respond quickly to globalisation processes and rapid changing consumer attitudes and preferences. Companies are confronted with a situation in which they want to innovate and develop products and services that suit the new demands of clients. This process of innovation is not only required of the R&D departments, but also of all other business processes, such as marketing, production management, supply chain management, customer care, etc. However, with all these new demands, companies find that some of their employees are not able to live up to these changes. There are a number of reasons for this. First, some employees do not have the necessary skills to adapt quickly to a dynamic marketplace. Second, they do not have a clear picture of how these changes will impact their jobs and working conditions. With this in mind, HRM will have to help to facilitate organisational change and to provide a clear perspective on what the company is trying to move to. The need for rapid change is putting additional pressure on employees, as many of these processes are not easily understood by the workforce to the same extent as the executives in the organisation. The main purpose of HRM in a change context is to ensure an effective match between the employees’ needs and the organisation’s strategic objectives and goals. This is the central job of HRM, ensuring a fair and equitable balance between the demands placed on the organisation by the market and the expectations of employees for fair treatment in the workplace (Wexley & Roth, 1988:56). How do employees manage job demands? There are a number of ways of looking at this important idea, and in the South African context it has been proposed that employees are confronted with both job demands and job resources (Higgins, 1987) (see Figure 8.1).
Job demands Job resources
HRM MANAGEMENT RESOURCES
Individual resources Time
Leadership style (HRM) Stressors
Several scholars have studied how workers manage job demands and resources using various different perspectives. For example, some scholars in this field, such as Driskell et al. (2001), have focused their studies more on the organisational resources perspective. These resources, such as the organisational control environment, organisational support and role clarity, were found to be important in the ability of employees to manage high levels of job demands (Driskell et al., 2001:41). The organisational demands model (Taylor et al., 2001) looks at the work environment from the perspective of the work environment, job demands and individual resources.
Following a literature review regarding the management of high levels of job demands (Driskell et al., 2001), the authors postulate that people need to possess certain individual resources, such as task- and self-management skills, emotional regulation and social support. They further point to the negative impact of some factors, such as stress, that could have the effect of eroding these valuable resources. 95
HRM can play a valuable role in reducing the detrimental effects of job demands and in promoting positive individual resource development. How do employees cope with job demands? The research study mentioned above indicates that employees with job resources handle job demands more effectively.
Furthermore, they are more likely to be proactive, adaptive, flexible and more innovative in the way that they deal with their jobs. Another study, one that was conducted by the same authors, examined the level of job burnout among employees based on perceived job demands and job resources (Wrzesniewski et al., 2001). In this case, the researchers found that employees with low levels of job burnout could handle the perceived level of job demands and that they perceived the positive resources of their jobs more positively.
8.3 Job demands/resources/performance nexus
As HRM managers it is important to consider how job demands and job resources impact not only individuals’ performance but also organisational performance. Most of the research in this field is focused in the area of individual performance, as many scholars are concerned in this area. In the South African context, some scholars have started to shift this focus and look at job demands and resources from the perspective of the group or the division of the organisation. These concerns are more related to how divisions respond to changing global conditions and demands in a relatively uncertain environment. This is where the idea of ‘organisational resilience’ becomes important. Organisational resilience, the ability of an organisation to respond to and adapt to change and to bounce back from external shocks, is becoming increasingly important in the global environment. 8.3.1 Job demands/resources/ individual performance
It will come as no surprise that job demands and job resources also impact employee performance (Wrzesniewski et al., 2001). Some of the important relationships between job demands and organisational performance are: •
There are important relationships between employees’ job demands and levels of job satisfaction, commitment, organisational citizenship behaviour and absenteeism (Spector, 1997).
Stressful jobs were found to be negatively related to organisational citizenship behaviour (Zapata-Banet et al., 2001).
Job demands–job resources were found to be a stronger predictor of job performance than job design variables, such as job content (Rodell & Barsness, 2003).
Job stress experienced by employees was associated with fewer organisational citizenship behaviours. At the same time, employees with more job resources and high levels of citizenship behaviours experienced lower levels of job stress.
Job resources were found to be a strong predictor of job performance and turnover intentions (Hellriegel & Slocum, 2005:406).

Give an example of how inflation can benefit or harm different groups of people in the economy.

instruction: Gross domestic product (GDP) and gross national product (GNP) are two common measures of a country’s economic performance. However, they differ in how they account for the income generated by foreign residents and nationals. Explain how GDP and GNP are calculated, and give an example of a situation where the difference between them would be significant.
combined_input: Gross domestic product (GDP) and gross national product (GNP) are two common measures of a country’s economic performance. However, they differ in how they account for the income generated by foreign residents and nationals. Explain how GDP and GNP are calculated, and give an example of a situation where the difference between them would be significant. menu longHOME destroy Linearactual HE
generated_output:
ADLONG
The economic value of resources is important to a country because it helps to measure its economic performance while also giving a clear idea about how much a country is worth and how much that will help in developing it.
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) refers to the total value of final goods sold and services rendered in a given country in a given period of time. That is, it calculates the total income earned and expenses incurred by residents or citizens of a nation during a specified period.
Gross National Product (GNP) is the sum of three components: national income (gross private income), income on national investments and income from national assets. It is a more comprehensive measure of economic activity than the GDP because it includes the income earned by foreign residents as well as those generated by citizens of the country being measured.
Gross National Product can be more significant than GDP in some instances. For example, an increase in the GNP may occur because of higher wages and a higher level of business profits, both of which can be seen as positive signs for the economy but do not actually represent increased economic activity.
The difference between gross domestic product and gross national product can be significant for a country’s economy. GDP represents the amount of economic activity within a country, while GNP represents the value of all the assets and investments owned by citizens and foreign residents in a country at any given time. GNP is therefore an important measure of a country’s net economic value.
However, there is not always a significant difference between GDP and GNP. The difference between them may depend on the exchange rate used to calculate the value of each.
For example, if the exchange rate used to calculate GDP is higher than the exchange rate used to calculate GNP, then the GNP will be greater than the GDP. Conversely, if the GNP is calculated using a lower exchange rate than that used to calculate GDP, then the difference between them will be less.
Gross domestic product (GDP) is the total value of final goods and services produced in an economy in a given year. Gross national product (GNP) is a measure of the total income earned by all individuals and businesses within a country during a given year.
While both GDP and GNP are important measures of economic performance, the difference between them can be significant. For example, when calculating GDP, the country’s population is taken into account while calculating GNP only includes income generated from within the country’s borders.
The difference also varies depending on the sector in which the calculation is made. The GDP includes government and foreign-owned entities while the GNP only includes domestically owned ones iii.e. excluding assets owned by foreign residents and foreign firms.
The biggest difference between Gross Domestic Product and Gross National Product comes down to how they’re calculated. For GDP, all the resources (human and natural) of a country are taken into account, while for GNP, only income generated by individuals residing in a country is counted.
Gross domestic product and gross national product are terms used to describe a country’s economic activity, though they can be used to describe the economic activity of an individual country or a group of individuals.
Both GDP and GNP are measures of economic activity, and both refer to the total value of goods and services produced within a country in a given year. GDP includes only those goods and services produced within that country, while GNP captures all economic activity within a country regardless of whether it happened within that country or elsewhere.
However, they do not directly answer this question – they are two separate measures of economic activity. While they may be calculated using similar data sets, their definitions and methods of calculations vary widely and they are often used for different purposes.
Gross domestic product (GDP) is a measure of the value of all final goods and services produced in a country during a particular year. Gross national product (GNP) includes the value of income earned by people and businesses in a country, no matter where they reside for work purposes (for example, expatriates).
The difference between them can therefore be significant because GDP represents the income generated by a country’s residents while GNP refers to the entire flow of resources across international borders. For instance, if all the resources of a company are spent within a country then GNP will be higher than GDP.
GDP and Gross National Product are key indicators of a country’s economic health. GDP measures the total output of a nation, while Gross National Product measures the income generated by citizens of a country. The difference between them can be significant, depending on the type of trade that is being evaluated.
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is an index that represents the total value of the goods and services produced within a country during a specific year. Gross National Product (GNP) is an index that represents the total income earned by citizens of a country during a specific period.
